text:
• a. Tabia claims that 12 is a factor of 24. How can you check whether she is correct?
  • b. How would you test whether 7 is a factor of 291?

a. Divide 24 by 12 to see if you get a whole number. Since 12 × 12 = 24 or 24 ÷ = 2, 12 is a factor of 24. Students may multiply 12 by 1, 2, 3... to see if you get 24. Division may not be their first method of checking.

b. Divide 291 by 7 to see if the answer is a whole number. Since 291 ÷ 7 = 41.571429..., 7 is not a factors of 291. Students may also write the multiples of 7 in a list and see if 291 is one of them.
• In the following Factor Game, some of the scores are missing on the tally sheet.
a. In Round 1, Cathy chose 24. Keiko scored 36 points. Make a game board. Mark Cathy's choice and Keiko's factors.

b. In Round 2, it is Keiko's turn. Cathy scored 21 points. What number did Keiko pick?

c. In Round 3, it is Cathy's turn. Keiko score 9 points. What number might Cathy have picked?

d. In Round 4, it is Keiko's turn. Keiko chose 30. What did Cathy score?

e. In Round 5, it is Cathy's turn. What is Cathy's best move? Explain your choice.

b. Keiko picked 28. Cathy scored 21 points for 7 and 14, the factor 28that were not already covered.

c. Cathy picked 18 or 27. Keiko scored 9 points by circling 9 (the factor of 18 or 27 that is not already covered).

d. Cathy scores 30 points for 5, 10, and 15 (the factors of 30 that are not already covered).

e. The only numbers remaining with open factors are 22(11) and 26(13). Cathy should choose 26 because she will score 13 more points than Keiko.

a. Which of the numbers 19, 21, 23, and 25 has the most factors?

b. Find a number greater than 25 that has more factors than the numbers in ACE 3a.

c. Find a number less than 19 that has more factors than the numbers in ACE 3a.

a. 21 has the most factors: 1 and 19 are the factors of 19; 1, 3, 7, and 21 are the factors of 21; 1 and 23 are the factors of 23; 1, 5, and 25 are the factors of 25.

b. Answers will vary. Possible answer is 36; 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, and 36 are the factos of 36. Students may just look at their table from Problem 1.1 and choose 28 (1, 2, 4, 7, 14, 28) or 30 (1,2,3, 5, 6, 10, 15, 30).

c. Answers will vary, Possible answer is 18; 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, and 18 are the factors of 18.
c. Which of these numbers are divisors of 64? 2, 6, 8, 12, 16
Sam knows that 3 is a factors of 24. This means that 3 × ? = 24. Another way to write thus us 3 × n = 24. For each statement, find a value of n that makes the statement true.
a. Suppose you place a chip on a prime number in the Factor Game. Your opponent receives at most 1 point. Explain why. Use examples.

In the Factor Game, your opponent scores points for proper factors of the number you choose. The only proper factor of prime numbers, such as 2, 3, and 7, is 1. Prime numbers have exactly two factors, 1 and themselves. The number itself is off the board once the person puts chip on it. The number 1 is all that is left on the board for the opponent.
b. Suppose you cover a composite number in the Factor Game. Your opponent might receive more points than you. Explain why. Give some examples.
Some numbers, such as 12, 20, and 30, have many proper factors that would give your opponent more points. (Some numbers, such as 9, 15, and 25, have fewer factors and would give you more points.)

Danika and Tomlynn are playing the Product Game.

Danika has markers on 12, 16, and 20.

Tomlynn has markers on 3, 10, and 21.

The paper clips are on 3 and 7. It is Danika's turn to move a paper clip.
a. List the moves Danika can make.

She can move the paper clip on the 3 and get multiples of 7 that are available on the board.

Or she can move the paper clip on the 7 and get multiples of 3 that are available on the board.

Multiples of 7 on the board:

7 ⋅ 1 = 7, 7 ⋅ 2 = 14, 7 ⋅ 4 = 28, 7 ⋅ 5 = 35, 7 ⋅ 6 = 42, 7 ⋅ 7 = 49, 7 ⋅ 8 = 56, 7 ⋅ 9 = 63
b. Which move(s) would give Danika three markers in a row?

6 → move the 7 to the 2, to get the product of 3 ⋅ 2.

18 → move the 7 to the 6, to get the product of 3 ⋅ 6.

28 → move the 3 to the 4, to get the product of 4 ⋅ 7.
c. Which move(s) would allow her to block Tomlynn?
35 → move the 3 to the 5, to get the product of 5 ⋅ 7
d. Which move(s) do you think Danika should make? Explain.

Possible answer:

Block Tomlynn so she cannot win.
a. Suppose that one paper clip on the Product Game board is on 3. What products can you make by moving the other paper clip?
b. List five multiples of 3 that are not on the game board.
c. How many multiples of 3 are there on the game board?
a. Davis just marked 18 on a Product Game board. On which factors might the paper clips be placed? List all possibilities.
1 and 18, but 18 is not a factor option on the board.
Salvador said that the Product Game could be called the Multiple Game. Do you agree? Why or why not?

Since the numbers on the game board are multiple of numbers given as possible factors, you could argue in support of Sal's position. The Product Game is more specific, because it implies the result of multiplying the two numbers together, while there are an infinite number of multiples of two chosen numbers.
Hank has a new card for the Algebra Connections game: 3N - 1 is a multiple of 2. What could N be?

3N - 1 is even, so 3N must be odd because any odd number minus 1 will be an even number. For 3N to be an odd number, N must be odd. An odd number times another odd number is always odd. Then N cannot be an even number, otherwise 3N would also be even because any odd number times an even is an even number. Therefore, N could be any odd number.
Determine whether each number can be made in more than one way in the Product Game. Say whether the number is prime or composite.
36 can be found on the Product Game board by 6 × 6 or 4 × . 36 is composite
5 can be found on the Product Game board by only 1 × 5. 5 is prime
7 can be found on the Product Game board by only 1 × 7. 7 is prime
9 can be found on the Product Game board by 1 × 9 or 3 × 3. 9 is composite.
A school band has 64 members. The band marches in the shape of a rectangle.
a. What rectangles can the band director make by arranging the band members?
b. Which of these arrangements is mot appealing to you? Why?
Answers will vary. Many students will choose the rectangle that is a square or square- like.
List the dimensions of each rectangle that can be made from the given number of tiles. Then list all the factor pairs for that number.

Thandiwe has chosen a mystery number. Her number is greater than 12 and less than 40. It has exactly three factors. What might her number be? Use the display of rectangles from Problem 1.3 to find Thandiwe's number. Also, think about what the displays for the numbers 31 to 40 would look like.
Her number is 25. Her number must be a square number because it has an odd number of factors. 16 has five factors, and 36 has nine factors.
The length of Adamma's rectangle is three times its width. What is the area of the rectangle, in terms of the width.

At a soccer game, a group os 100 volunteers in the stadium will hold up cards to form pictures. Each display uses 100 square cards. They are most effective when the volunteers sit in a rectangular arrangement. What rectangular seating arrangements are possible? Which arrangements wuld you choose? Why?

100 fans in 1 row, 50 fans in 2 rows, 25 fans in 4 rows, 20 fans in 5 rows, 10 fans in 10 rows, 5 fans in 20 rows, 4 fans in 25 rows, 2 fans in 50 rows, or 1 fan in 100 rows.

Answers about which arrangement to choose will vary.

Sample: I would rather have one long banner that wraps around part of the stadium, so I would choose 100 fans in 1 row.

Sample: I would rather have a big square that you couls see on TV, so I would choose 10 fans in 10 rows.
a. Ms. Diaz wants to divide her class of 30 students into 10 groups. The groups do not need to be of equal size. What are some of her choices?
Various answers; for example, group sizes 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 3, 2, 2,3, and 2. The goal is to find 10 numbers whose sum is 30.
b. Ms. Diaz wants to divide her class of 30 students into equal-sized groups. What are her choices>

She could have 1 group of 30 students, 2 groups of 15 students each, 3 groups of 10 students each, 5 groups of 6 students each, 6 groups of 5 students each, 10 groups of 3 students each, 15 groups of 2 students each, or 30 groups of 1 student each.
c. How is the thinking you did in ACE 18a different from the thinking you did in ACE 18b?
In ACE 18a, the sum of the numbers in the ten groupd must be 30. In ACE 18b, we are considering the factors of 30.
a. The following calculator screen shows the result of dividing 84 by 14. What does the answer tell you about 14 and 84?
6; Since the result is a whole number, 14 is a factor of 84.
b. The following calculator screen shows the result of dividing 84 by 15. What does the answer tell you about 15 and 84?
5.6; Since the result is not a whole number, 15 is not a factor of 84.

As part of the carnival, the school will hold a Factor Game marathon. It takes Nala and Tierra an average of 12 minutes to finish one game. About how many games will they finish if they play nonstop from 9:00a.m. to 2:30p.m.?
5 hours × 60 (minutes/ hour) = 300 minutes; 300 + 30 = 330 minutes. 330 ÷ 12 = 27.5. Therefore, they can play 27 games.

Multiple Choice Carlos read a book for language arts class. He finished the book on Friday. On Monday, je read 27 pages. On Tuesday, he read 31 pages. On Wednesday, he read 28 pages, On Thursday and Friday, he read the same number of pages each day. The book has 144 pages. How many pages did he read on Thursday?

A. 28

B. 29

C. 31

D. 58

Answer: B; Carlos read 27 + 31 + 28 = 86 pages the first part of the week. He had 144 - 86 = 58 pages left for Thursday and Friday. Since he read the same number of pages each day, 58 ÷ 2 = 29. Carlos read 29 pages on Thursday.
a. For what values of n will the sum n + 3 be less than 50?
b. For what values of n will the product 3n be less than 50?
a. Long ago, people decided to divide the day into units called hours. They chose 24 as the number of hours in one day. Why is 24 a more convenient choice than 23 or 25?

24 has many factors, so it can be divided into many equal parts. Since 23 is prime, it cannot be subdivided. The only proper factors of 25 are 1 and 5, so it can only be subdivided into 5 groups of 5.
b. In developing the ways of calculating time, astronomers divided an hour into 60 minutes. Why is 60 a better choice than 59 or 61?
Because 60 has many factors and 50 and 61 do not.
Ramona's aunt has saved $10,000 in $20 bills. She spends one $20 bill every day. How many days will it take her to run out of bills?

The expression 3 × n can be written without the multiplication sign as 3n. For each expression in ACE 25a-c, do the following:

  1. Use n = 1, 2, 3, ..., 10 to evaluate the expression
  2. Describe the set of ten numbers.
  3. Suppose the sequence continues for values of n greater than 10. Do the numbers 12, 21, 30, or 210 appear in the sequence?

1. 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, 30.
  2. Multiples of 3; 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, and 30.
  3. 12, 21, 30, and 210 will all appear in the sequence, because they are all multiples of 3.

1. 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49, 56, 63, 70.
  2. Multiples of 7.
  3. 21 and 210 will appear in the sequence, because they are multiples of 7.

1. 6 × 1 = 6; 6 × 2 = 12; 6 × 3 = 18; 6 × 4 =24; 6 × 5 = 30; 6 × 6 = 36; 6 × 7 = 42; 6 × 8 =48; 6 × 9 = 54; and 6 × 10 = 60.
  2. Multiples of 6.
  3. 12, 30, and 210 will appear in the sequence, because they are multiples of 6.
Querida and Moesha decide to pay the Factor Game on a 100 board. A 100 board includes whole numbers from 1 to 100.
a. What will Querida score is Moesha chooses 100 as her first move?
b. What will Querida score is Moesha chooses 99 as her first move?
c. What is the best first move on a 100-board?
97, because it is the largest prime less than 100.
The Factor Game can be played on a 49 board that includes the whole numbers from 1 to 49.
a. Extend your table for analyzing first moves on a 30 board to include all the numbers on a 49 board.
c. What new square numbers can you find?
d. What is the best first move on a 40 board? Why?
e. What is the wirst firt move on a 49 board, other than 1? Why?

What number am I?

Clue 1. When you divide me by 5, the remainder is 4.

Clue 2. I have two digits. Both digits are odd.

Clue 3. The sum of my digits is 10.

The sum of the proper factors of a number may be greater than, less than, or equal to the number. Mathematicians use this idea to classify numbers as abundant, deficient, or perfect. Each whole number greater than 1 falls into one of these three categories.
a. Draw and label three circles as shown. The numbers 12, 15, and 6 have been placed in the appropriate circles.
Use your factor list to determine what each label means. Then, write each whole number from 2 to 30 in the correct circle.
b. Are the labels appropriate? Why or why not?

Paloma works on many factor problems. She notices that her factor pair list often starts with pairs of numbers such as 1 × 100, 2 × 50, and 4 × 25. Her factor list ends with 25 × 4, 50 × 2, and 100 × 1. At some point, the list begins to repeat the factor pairs in reversed order.
a. Consider the factor pairs of 100. When do the factor pairs reverse order?
b. Consider the factor pairs of 81. When do the factor pairs reverse order?
c. For any square number, when do the factor pairs reverse order?
d. Think about a number that is not a square number. At what point will the factor pairs reverse order? Explain.
e. Is there a point at which a prime number's factor pairs reverse order?

Nuru is trying to determine when he can stop looking for more whole- number factors of a number. He has collected data about several numbers. For example, 30 has 1 × 30, 2 × 15, 3 × 10, and 5 × 6 as factor pairs. Then, he can stop looking because the factor pairs repeat. For 36, he can stop looking when he gets to 6 × 6. For 66, there are no new factor pairs after 6 × 11.

Copy and complete the following table. Is there any pattern that would help Nuru find the point where the factor pairs reverse order?
For ACE 32a-c, find composite numbers that can be rewritten as the following:
b. the product of a prime number and another composite number
d. Oba thinks he can find examples of prime numbers that he can write as a product of two primes. Is he correct? Give some examples or explain why not.
